messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: When to Update Your Model: Constrained Model-based Reinforcement Learning

Paper Abstract: Abstract Designing and analyzing model-based RL (MBRL) algorithms with guaranteed monotonic improvement has been challenging, mainly due to the interdependence between policy optimization and model learning. Existing discrepancy bounds generally ignore the impacts of model shifts, and their corresponding algorithms are prone to degrade performance by drastic model updating. In this work, we first propose a novel and general theoretical scheme for a non-decreasing performance guarantee of MBRL. Our follow-up derived bounds reveal the relationship between model shifts and performance improvement. These discoveries encourage us to formulate a constrained lower-bound optimization problem to permit the monotonicity of MBRL. A further example demonstrates that learning models from a dynamically-varying number of explorations benefit the eventual returns. Motivated by these analyses, we design a simple but effective algorithm CMLO111Code is available in https://github.com/jity16/When-to-Update-Your-Model-Constrained-Model-based-Reinforcement-Learning. (Constrained Model-shift Lower-bound Optimization), by introducing an event-triggered mechanism that flexibly determines when to update the model. Experiments show that CMLO surpasses other state-of-the-art methods and produces a boost when various policy optimization methods are employed.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Model-based reinforcement learning with a generative model is minimax optimal",
        "Robel: Robotics benchmarks for learning with low-cost robots",
        "Differentiable mpc for end-to-end planning and control",
        "Lipschitz continuity in model-based reinforcement learning",
        "Minimax pac bounds on the sample complexity of reinforcement learning with a generative model",
        "Openai gym",
        "Sample-efficient reinforcement learning with stochastic ensemble value expansion",
        "Deep reinforcement learning in a handful of trials using probabilistic dynamics models",
        "Learning to control a low-cost manipulator using data-efficient reinforcement learning",
        "Tight regret bounds for model-based reinforcement learning with greedy policies",
        "Model-based reinforcement learning for continuous control with posterior sampling",
        "Value-aware loss function for model-based reinforcement learning",
        "Model-based value estimation for efficient model-free reinforcement learning",
        "Addressing function approximation error in actor-critic methods",
        "Improving pilco with bayesian neural network dynamics models",
        "Soft actor-critic: Off-policy maximum entropy deep reinforcement learning with a stochastic actor",
        "An introduction to event-triggered and self-triggered control",
        "Rtmba: A real-time model-based reinforcement learning architecture for robot control",
        "Pyrep: Bringing v-rep to deep robot learning",
        "When to trust your model: Model-based policy optimization",
        "Reinforcement learning: A survey",
        "Approximately optimal approximate reinforcement learning",
        "Information theoretic regret bounds for online nonlinear control",
        "Uncertainty-driven imagination for continuous deep reinforcement learning",
        "A sparse sampling algorithm for near-optimal planning in large markov decision processes",
        "Gp-bayesfilters: Bayesian filtering using gaussian process prediction and observation models",
        "Model-ensemble trust-region policy optimization",
        "On effective scheduling of model-based reinforcement learning",
        "Guided policy search",
        "End-to-end training of deep visuomotor policies",
        "Breaking the sample size barrier in model-based reinforcement learning with a generative model",
        "Event-triggered robust model predictive control of continuous-time nonlinear systems",
        "Continuous control with deep reinforcement learning",
        "Algorithmic framework for model-based deep reinforcement learning with theoretical guarantees",
        "Playing atari with deep reinforcement learning",
        "Human-level control through deep reinforcement learning",
        "Minimax differential dynamic programming: An application to robust biped walking",
        "Neural network dynamics for model-based deep reinforcement learning with model-free fine-tuning",
        "Trust the model when it is confident: Masked model-based actor-critic",
        "Mbrl-lib: A modular library for model-based reinforcement learning",
        "Survey of model-based reinforcement learning: Applications on robotics",
        "pytorch-soft-actor-critic",
        "Markov decision processes: discrete stochastic dynamic programming",
        "Trust region policy optimization",
        "High-dimensional continuous control using generalized advantage estimation",
        "Proximal policy optimization algorithms",
        "Near-optimal time and sample complexities for solving discounted markov decision process with a generative model",
        "Mastering the game of go with deep neural networks and tree search",
        "Dual policy iteration",
        "Integrated architecture for learning, planning, and reacting based on approximating dynamic programming",
        "Dyna, an integrated architecture for learning, planning, and reacting",
        "Planning by incremental dynamic programming",
        "Reinforcement learning: An introduction",
        "Mujoco: A physics engine for model-based control",
        "Benchmarking model-based reinforcement learning",
        "Inequalities for the l1 deviation of the empirical distribution",
        "Mopo: Model-based offline policy optimization"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in When to Update Your Model: Constrained Model-based Reinforcement Learning, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
